Name: N Paul
Comment: Looking back, they did one hell of a good job managing the fallout of this. This was serious enough to wreck the reputation of even established players, and they really started kicking it once they moved to crisis management mode. The decision to discontinue this phone was simply brilliant...any other choice would have been catastrophic. Their communication after x2 was great, and they went the long mile with the fire-resistant shipping materials they spent a fortune on to get the devices back...which was a sold investment as as a high-profile incident during return (though unlikely given the lack of charging) could have been the nail in the coffin. The hit they took buying the devices back for more than owners originally paid was also the right call.

@ZettabyteGamer Um.. not. Clearing it will will "close" the app and clear cache. I am a note 4 user and I experience it daily. If I clear all open apps in recent apps, it will either log me out and clear all cache. For example, if I were to just exit apps using the home button, the apps will still save where I was and when I go back to the apps, it will open at exactly where I exited (except some apps that automatically log you out for security purposes) but if do "close all open app" in recent apps tab, it all cause apps to completely close and when I go back to the apps, it will open with log in screen/initial open pages.
@***** Yes thats what I said, if you clear the apps in cache they will take longer to open.
+ZettabyteGamer but they'll also stop running so you get a slight performance increase and a decent battery boost.
@***** No you wont, putting them into cache makes them stop running. They just launch faster. Clearing cache does not increase performance or battery life.
I'm not talking about cleaning cache I'm talking about actually "closing" recent apps
@***** Closing recent apps is clearing them from cache.
No, it's not.  It's clearing them from RAM.  Two different things, my friend.
@Super Luigi 64 I'm referring to a RAM cache, saying RAM or just cache is still referring to a RAM cache.

@ZettabyteGamer What are you talking about, android was designed to not "kill" apps when the user "soft" leaves them, they just "pause" themselves and keep running.

Following that logic, OnePlus partial "RAM cap" to save battery on OnePlus 3 and even my custom LMK values on my low end device do nothing.

@***** "What are you talking about, android was designed to not "kill" apps when the user "soft" leaves them, they just "pause" themselves and keep running." Yes thats called putting them in cache, and thats what android does. But when the operating system starts running out of RAM to put new apps into they kill the older ones, and remove them from cache.
@ZettabyteGamer your so stupid....obviously youve only owened an iphone....therefore what you buy is what you are...uninformed
#triggered

@ZettabyteGamer "Yes thats called putting them in cache, and thats what android does."

From what I know, Android does that only when the user actually closes the app, not when he "temporarily leaves" them (through recents or home button for example)

@***** When the user actually closes the app it is just closed. The point of putting it in cache is so that the app can be reopened really fast, and be right where you left off. If a user closes the app it would be a waste of resources to keep it in cache.
Intentional explosions? LOL,  what a lousy excuse.

@ZettabyteGamer​ When the user closes an app, the app is killed but its memory isn't "fully purged" from RAM (so in case the user opens it again, it loads slightly faster). The app memory is only fully purged when the needed/free RAM amount gets below a specific value (see "empty app" LMK value).

When the simply leaves an app, without actually closing it, the app gets in the pause state but it stays somehow running in the background.

If it doesn't works like that, dare to explain why oneplus ram cap increases battery life and why my ultra low end device gets slightly smoother when using higher LMK values ?

@***** Dude I'm saying the exact same thing as you. When I say close I mean the users swipes the app out of the recent app screen, and kills the app. When they simply leave the app and go to another one the previous app is stored in cache, and if the user returns to it they will be right where they left off.

+CAPTAINJAMESLIM One example where an app has more functionality over Android and always has is Skype. The IOS version has the ability to change the settings directly in the app rather than online, it has the ability to change your status to Away or Busy, etc. while Android only has Invisible or Online.

Then we have even Google's own app having more features in the IOS Google App than the Android version. Tabs in the Google app on IOS for one example.

@CAPTAINJAMESLIM I never noticed until I got the Mini 4 and started to use the same apps. My main phone was Note 4 and my Table was the Mini 4. Name: Austin Flygare
Comment: Honestly, I disagree with you on the tossup between the s7 edge and the note 7. I received an s7 edge as a loaner during the recall and I was very disappointed with the device's performance. I may have gotten a bad unit but the one I received got warm much faster than my original note and was much warmer overall with any sort of moderate use as well as wireless charging. The phone lagged quite often too, especially when bringing up the keyboard on screen and the battery life was miserable. Wrapping an 8 hour work day, my note was generally around 57% is percent, while my S7 Edge was consistently around 35%. I had everything set up almost the same for both devices but the S7 always seemed to burn through battery awfully fast for sitting in a pocket. One day it actually became so warm in my pocket that I was worried about permanent damage to the device, it was EXTREMELY hot to the touch just from sitting IDLE! Overall though, I'm VERY happy with the Note 7 and this is coming from a person who I had the iPhone 4, 4s, 5, 6, 6 plus and 6s plus as well as more than a handful of Android phones including the galaxy s5, s6 droid incredible, droid RAZR and a few others. I won't be switching back to iOS for quite awhile

expandable storage, wireless charging, water resistance, better camera, better battery life, MUCH better screen colors and resolution, more apps on the store, TV-remote support, file management, free music, free paid apps, Qualcomm fast charging (60% in 30 mins), setting default apps, more lockscreen options, WAY of customization, widgets, app drawer, back button, Multi window, better notification organization/management, Google Now, Google Now on Tap, Samsung Pay (Pay anywhere that has a credit card reader. apple pay only works in select stores), Launchers and custom ROMs, Google integration, OTG support (plug a USB in your phone), more sharing options, better app storage/permissions management, Individual user profiles, NFC can be used anywhere (Not just payment), Installing apps from third party stores, free in-app purchases (with root), universal Bluetooth sharing, Adobe flash support, etc
All off the top of my head... I will admit, some of those features I personally don't use. but there are some extremely useful little things that I really love about Android and its flexibility

It's up to you but I personally like iPhone. Apple still provides software updates to their old phones, upto the iPhone 5 (I think). unlike Samsung and many other android companies. They lose support after one or two years although you can always flash rom, but that's not my thing and it takes like two or more months for the phone to get updated once Google releases a andriod new version. I don't think you should switch just because you like facetiming and messaging, there are many apps that provide that for free although it requires Internet and also for the other person to get it. There are a lot less feature on the iPhone but I don't use most of the feature on androids anyway like screen casting, multi window (having two apps open at the same time). iPhone is definitely faster then android although I don't think you will notice it much. It loads app quicker, turns on faster but it's not a realy big difference, it's  only a few second difference which you won't notice. The build qualities are nice whether your buying a iPhone or any android cause it's 2016 now.

A great phone display screen wasn't convincing for me
Yesterday i had to wipe off the phone data (factory restore) after my defected note 7 stopped responding and the battery temperature slowly start to rise
I did it after i pressed all the buttons at the same time
Disconnecting the phone battery is very important for any sealed system the consumer should have full control over the power source of any device... they can simply add a physical switch that can do the job internally
Sometimes the phone can freeze and stop responding to any function including the power button
Coming from the excellent samsung s3 i say closed system phones are not practical in the long run
I think I'm going toward the lg v20 this year

Carlos Alberto Morales Well, I guess it all comes down to personal preference and needs. I need a smartphone that can read and edit documents, while also being fast and simple. The iPhone 7 Plus does all of these things brilliantly. As for the stylus functionality, I don't think I would use it enough for it to be worth leaving what, in my opinion, is one of the fastest and simplest smartphone operating systems out there. The multitasking feature is a nice bonus, but still, with only 5.7 inches of screen estate, what more productivity you can get out of this function is very limited. I have an iPad Air 2, and even there, with a 9.7 inch screen I'm still finding things a bit crammed together when I use the multitasking feature. I always plan things in advance, so i rarely find the need to quick charge my phone right before trips or in the morning. As of now, the only thing I hope for from Apple is the wireless charging. Other than that, I think the iPhone 7 Plus is the perfect smartphone for me, with a simple and snappy OS that utilizes all the potential power of the phone, while looking stunning at the same time. But I also think the Note 7 is a great smartphone with lots of functionality. Then again, if you really need a portable office, why not have something like the Surface Pro? There are limitations to what can be done on a smartphone, and I think an Ultrabook or a Notebook is the best option if you're going to do really heavy work on the go.
Carlos Alberto Morales Exactly. The best option is what fits your needs the most :-)

Name: tttekev
Comment:
Great review as always Marques, keep up the good work! A few things though.

1. This is most likely a bug with Samsungs aggressive power management features when the device is locked. They majorly downclick the CPU in order to save battery life. The problem by doing this is if a computational task is already going on when you're unlocking the phone, it will lag until the unlock process completes and up-clocks the processor to typical levels. Samsung is probably more aggressive with this on the Note because of it's smaller battery. You've probably noticed it with a handful of Android devices.

2. I'm guessing that you're writing this review before the water-resistant iPhone came out. But the speakers on the new iPhone 7 and 7 Plus are amazing with water-resistant speakers. So at least in my opinion, the lower, tinny sound from the S7, S7 Edge, and Note are no excuse at this point.

Comment: I used to love his channel.  There isn't really anything special about it anymore.  His reviews come later than everyone else's, and by the time he does publish them we basically know everything about the phones already (aside from the fact that he got the IP certification number wrong in this one).  Yes, the camera quality in his vids are good, but so are most YouTube tech reviewers nowadays.  Should we should expect his LG V20 review some time in January?  Let's go, Marques.  You were the top tech reviewer on YouTube for good reason.  You stood out.  Now some clown who bent an iPhone is labeled as the top tech reviewer.

Reply: This video particularly probably took longer because of the recall. I was waiting for it too but I did get why it had to be delayed. Besides he does have to take time to thoroughly review everything about the phone and even included the issues about the battery and waited for his unit to be swapped out for a new one. That for me was a smart move. And he always provides us with the best content anyway so I guess that makes up for it

I'd say his reviews are about how they fare after a certain amount of time. What if the device quickly drops off in performance. A lot of people want to be the first to put out content with which they don't get a good enough experience with the products. Or maybe he doesn't care about being first.

I get both of your points (very valid!), however what did he say in the vid that was so different from everyone else's that DIDN'T wait a bit to publish?  That's all I'm saying.  Still a huge fan of his, however his vids feel a bit stale as other review channels have seemed to catch up.

I like his reviews because he use the phone and then reviews it and tell how it perform after sometime not like others who just get the phone and review, because some phones may look good at start but after some use you will find more about them, so it's better to use first and then review it.
Vtgh
he has to start to daily vlog now, like everybody else :D
@iLLSHa Cephied thanks for the reply.  Guess you've never heard of constructive criticism? Didn't know I said anything bad about his videos... and guessing you didn't read my entire comment either.
@Tech Check lol.. oh please no...

like the others say, he uses the phone first. The reviews may not differ much from others but you know he uses it first and gives a review based on his experience. For example he states that sometimes when he opens the Note7 it lags a little bit at first. I have the S6 and that happens to me too now and then, so it let's me know that samsung still has that issue. It's the little details, it's no biggie, but I feel MKBHD tries his best to give a good, honest review not to be 1st and get views but to inform his audience.

@Pure Luck​ well said, also people who reviews early didnt know there is battery issue once people start using it then it was found. One more thing after using the phone you can tell how much time battery can last, early reviewer can't tell that accurately

Reviews aren't supposed to come early, that's the reason he kept another section called First Impressions. He takes his time, uses the device, checks battery and camera performance, compares it with the previous models and other phones and then concludes whether it's worth a buy. That's how good reviewers do it.
MKBHD is a top dog. If you get a chance check out my channel.

TWorldTV The reason we watch his reviews is because we want his opinions. If you want to watch a "features" video, that's a different story. Comment:
You forgot to mention this so you can make your phone a bit more faster.
Tap the build number for 7 times to enable developer options. Once you've enabled developer options, develop options will appear in settings just above the About device option. Open developer options scroll down till you see the 3 animation's and make them from 1x to .05x and it will increase tour speed. Also to root your device and you have the Fap lock on so it wont work so turn it off by doing this: Tap the build number for 7 times to enable developer options. Once you've enabled developer options, develop options will appear in settings just above the About device option. Open developer options, the 4th or 5th option should be “OEM Unlock”. Turn on the small icon next to it and that's all.

This may be the only time I haven't clicked thumbs up or down on your video. We are best friends, but you don't know that, lol (because I have heard you talk more than any other friend, hahaha.) I skipped Note 5, because they disappointed me (not because it wasn't a major upgrade from mine, but because they left so much opportunity out they could have done.) So the S7 came out and got me excited the Note 7 was going to be brilliant. Remember how Notes piloted all the best of the best and it wasn't the S Series? Well, not the case any more!

Okay, so why didn't I give it a thumbs up? You waited forever. I'm sure u needed to see what was going to happen about the explosions. And I defended Samsung until my brain hurts. They have so much to do to change their reputation from this, it hurt them so bad. But I couldn't get one when I was defending them, Oct. 4th and Google has me waiting, and now hearing about the S8..........makes me not want this phone again. Knowing they have to do alot to redeem themselves, I thought there would be some great bargains (throw in that charging case for your lame battery or give me 6 Gigs to say "I'm sorry.") Alas, no. I'm so frustarted, typing anything further sounds like whining. 1.) Please don't wait this long again for EVERYONE'S daily driver. 2.) Another elephant not addressed is should I buy the plus sized 67 over this, since it is everything and a better battery and cheaper or are the perks really worth it? 3.) Start-up lag: its because the OS is probably clearing your RAM and cache assuming u will use something new when u start it up again. Sadly what that means is that you have a paging lag as the pages are pulled into memory. No big deal...anything with a virtual memory will have this lag depending upon how well the page re-use scheme aligns with your usage behavior.

+Marques Brownlee: What do you think is the best portable/small yet powerful and long-lasting (in terms of battery life) smartphone? @***** I actually now believe the hard g to be the correct pronunciation. The creator was making a joke when he said "choosy develops choose 'jif'", making a joke off of the peanut butter brand. So if Jif the brand did not exist, he would've had no basis at all for the soft g (not that there is one anyway). The whole reason he had to explicitly state how he pronounces it is because it goes against the natural pronounciation. And as the chief editor of the Oxford English dictionary has said, the coiner effectively loses control over a word once it's out there.
The creator chose a pronunciation that does not make sense.
This website goes more in depth on these arguments and more: http://howtoreallypronouncegif.com
Why is it an unnatural pronunciation? Giraffe. Giant. Gigantic. A G being soft in front of an I is nothing new.

Comment: It is not worth the price. Full stop. It is bias to suggest it is IMO. By release time in Nov (UK) at £850 it will have a year old chipset that has been superseded. I'm on the iPad Air 2 right now, I'm gonna tell you my experience. This iPad breaks easily, now saying that I take care of my electronics a lot! I don't think it'll be anything major, it is a thin device, please invest in a case and screen protector. My headphone jack is broken but Bluetooth headphones are the saviour. I'm an android nerd, but I wanted to air 2 because I'm open to try new devices. I don't know why but my IPad glitches when I'm typing, actually it's happening right now. However, don't think this is negative because I really love this to watch YouTube videos, since it has a clean sleek design. I'm also an artist so drawing with this is basically amazing! (I'm saving up for an apple pen or an actual drawing tablet)  if you like to organize this is nice for that, however that's what an air 1 can do too. Overall I like the iPad it's not too "distracting" it gets the job done. However I don't know if you should buy this for anymore than 500 dollars. I have no experience with the note 7, however I do think it's nice to give a chance to android. Props to you! The note 7 looks so economical and so diverse. You can change the theme, but my main selling point is that S-pen. If I were you I'd find a main focus for both devices: for me on the iPad Air 2 was gaming and YouTube, and for the Note 7 is the S-pen (again I'm an artist) find something that suits YOUR needs.

Go with the S7 Edge because it's the smarter choice. Here are my reasons why:
*It is $100 cheaper with the same internals, minus the slightly smaller display (5.5 vs 5.7).
*The Note 7s CGG 5 is apparently super weak against scratches (from JerryRigsEverything's video).
*S Pen is useless for me. It's nice, but I've never felt I need a pen for my touch screen.
*Bigger battery, which is crucial for gaming.
*No battery issues unlike Note 7. Yes there's a recall and replacement devices are being made, but Samsung just announced that they need more time.
*Retinal scanner? No, I don't want to give more biometric data to the government.

That's everything I can think of right now. Maybe there's a few more, but I think this is a pretty compelling list for the S7.

-the scratches were apparently residue. CGG5 is definitely more searchable than 4, but not by 3 levels on the scale of hardness.
-100mah better. That's barely noticeable and shouldn't be enough to change anyone's mind one way or another.
-the government already has your biometric data and the iris scanner data stays on your phone anyways

the only real consideration is size and S-Pen. Are you ok with a bigger, squarer device? Do you want/need a stylus? Is it enough to justify the extra costs?

For me, it was worth it.

The camera was awesome (12mp with Xenon flash and even the autofocus focus orange light), the support it had for several peripherals was awesome (mouse, keyboard, PS3 remote, wii remote, etc), the dedicated hdmi port and 5.1 Surround support, the typical thin charger and the micro USB port on the side allowed to charge even when u were using the USB port for anything else. Well they had the Maemo OS on the Nokia n900 (I still have it) and also the Nokia n9 with the developed version of Maemo called Meego. And meego was awesome. So that and the fact they said NO to android from the start killed Nokia for me and, as we know now killed Nokia in the phones business.

Name: Jeff Woods
Comment:
I've been delaying an upgrade from my trusty Note3 to newer Note phones because I use microSD expansion, USB3, and replaceable batteries.

I have the external battery charger accessory for the Note3 from Samsung and 3 batteries. When out and about I carry the phone and a spare battery (in the battery case included with the charger) while the 3rd battery is at home in the charger. If I'm going to be gone longer than 2 batteries may last I can unplug the charger and use it as an additional battery case.

Replaceable battery and external charger from Samsung are all the Note7 doesn't provide that I want. I'm going to try upgrading to it and see if I can live with the limited battery capacity.

Also, if the Note7 had a replaceable battery then Samsung and Note7 customers would only have needed to replace the battery, not the whole phone. Wouldn't that have been much simpler, more convenient, and less expensive all around?

Samsung: Bring back replaceable batteries!

Actually, people are not as ignorant as you seem to think, but you, however, have a tenuous grasp of tenses in the English language. In constructing an if-then hypothetical, you (inadvertently, no doubt) mixed tenses, which is incorrect. Example: If you'd (or you HAD HAD) a dollar for every...you would HAVE HAD a few dollars. This puts both clauses in the past perfect tense.  Also, "you'd" is not a compound word in any possible sense, though it is a contraction of either, which you did note as examples, so that's a point your favor, even if the rest of your diatribe is specious in the extreme. Really, though, the bottom line is that you have been unnecessarily rude to someone you don't even know for no reason.  [A retired professor of English]

Comment:
Nice review but.... Upgrading from the S7 edge to the Note 7 has more benefits than just a S pen.

1. Touch ID has definately been improved
2. The Iris scanner is very useful for wet or gloved hands and its hell fast once it get used wth your eye.
3. The S pen of course
4. The display is definately brighter and the HDR is noticeable
5. I have the dual sim so a 64gig HD is very useful
6. It is a much better feel in the hand and its best looking mobile in a market.
7. The USB Type C and multiple benefits
8. The upgraded software and battery saving improvements are very useful
9. Change over now and you get a good resell value on your s7 edge
10. The larger screen is always appreciated even if its only minor.
11. Finger print scanner is cool.
In s7 edge you need to light up screen then you have to use finger print, but in Note 7 you just have to click the home key , finger print recognize right away !
And it's fast i love my note 7.
